segment.source: Step by step Surface Deployment Accelerator (Surface)
segment.target: Step by step Surface Deployment Accelerator (Surface)

segment.source: This article shows you how to install Microsoft Surface Deployment Accelerator (SDA), configure a deployment share for the deployment of Windows to Surface devices, and perform a deployment to Surface devices.
segment.target: This article shows you how to install Microsoft Surface Deployment Accelerator (SDA), configure a deployment share for the deployment of Windows to Surface devices, and perform a deployment to Surface devices.

segment.source: Step by step: Surface Deployment Accelerator
segment.target: Step by step: Surface Deployment Accelerator

segment.source: This article shows you how to install Microsoft Surface Deployment Accelerator (SDA), configure a deployment share for the deployment of Windows to Surface devices, and perform a deployment to Surface devices.
segment.target: This article shows you how to install Microsoft Surface Deployment Accelerator (SDA), configure a deployment share for the deployment of Windows to Surface devices, and perform a deployment to Surface devices.

segment.source: This article also contains instructions on how to perform these tasks without an Internet connection or without support for Windows Deployment Services network boot (PXE).
segment.target: This article also contains instructions on how to perform these tasks without an Internet connection or without support for Windows Deployment Services network boot (PXE).

segment.source: How to install Surface Deployment Accelerator
segment.target: How to install Surface Deployment Accelerator

segment.source: For information about prerequisites and instructions for how to download and install SDA, see Microsoft Surface Deployment Accelerator.
segment.target: For information about prerequisites and instructions for how to download and install SDA, see Microsoft Surface Deployment Accelerator.

segment.source: Download SDA, which is included in Surface Tools for IT on the Microsoft Download Center.
segment.target: Download SDA, which is included in Surface Tools for IT on the Microsoft Download Center.

segment.source: Run the SDA installation file, named SurfaceDeploymentAcceleratorxxxx.msi, where xxxx is the current version number.
segment.target: Run the SDA installation file, named SurfaceDeploymentAcceleratorxxxx.msi, where xxxx is the current version number.

segment.source: Accept the End User License Agreement (EULA) by selecting the check box, and then click Install, as shown in Figure 1.
segment.target: Accept the End User License Agreement (EULA) by selecting the check box, and then click Install, as shown in Figure 1.

segment.source: Surface Deployment Accelerator setup
segment.target: Surface Deployment Accelerator setup

segment.source: Figure 1.
segment.target: Figure 1.

segment.source: SDA setup
segment.target: SDA setup

segment.source: Click Finish to complete the installation of SDA.
segment.target: Click Finish to complete the installation of SDA.

segment.source: The tool installs in the SDA program group, as shown in Figure 2.
segment.target: The tool installs in the SDA program group, as shown in Figure 2.

segment.source: SDA program group and icon
segment.target: SDA program group and icon

segment.source: Figure 2.
segment.target: Figure 2.

segment.source: The SDA program group and icon
segment.target: The SDA program group and icon

segment.source: Note: At this point the tool has not yet prepared any deployment environment or downloaded any materials from the Internet.
segment.target: Note: At this point the tool has not yet prepared any deployment environment or downloaded any materials from the Internet.

segment.source: Create a deployment share
segment.target: Create a deployment share

segment.source: The following steps show you how to create a deployment share for Windows 10 that supports Surface 3, Surface Pro 3, Surface Pro 4, Surface Book, the Surface Firmware Tool, the Surface Asset Tag Tool, and Office 365.
segment.target: The following steps show you how to create a deployment share for Windows 10 that supports Surface 3, Surface Pro 3, Surface Pro 4, Surface Book, the Surface Firmware Tool, the Surface Asset Tag Tool, and Office 365.

segment.source: As you follow the steps below, make the selections that are applicable for your organization.
segment.target: As you follow the steps below, make the selections that are applicable for your organization.

segment.source: For example, you could choose to deploy Windows 10 to Surface Book only, without any of the Surface apps.
segment.target: For example, you could choose to deploy Windows 10 to Surface Book only, without any of the Surface apps.

segment.source: Note: SDA lets you create deployment shares for both Windows 8.1 and Windows 10 deployments, but you can only create a single deployment share at a time.
segment.target: Note: SDA lets you create deployment shares for both Windows 8.1 and Windows 10 deployments, but you can only create a single deployment share at a time.

segment.source: Therefore, to create both Windows 8.1 and Windows 10 deployment shares, you will need to run the tool twice.
segment.target: Therefore, to create both Windows 8.1 and Windows 10 deployment shares, you will need to run the tool twice.

segment.source: Open the SDA wizard by double-clicking the icon in the Surface Deployment Accelerator program group on the Start screen.
segment.target: Open the SDA wizard by double-clicking the icon in the Surface Deployment Accelerator program group on the Start screen.

segment.source: On the Welcome page, click Next to continue.
segment.target: On the Welcome page, click Next to continue.

segment.source: On the Verify System page, the SDA wizard verifies the prerequisites required for an SDA deployment share.
segment.target: On the Verify System page, the SDA wizard verifies the prerequisites required for an SDA deployment share.

segment.source: This process also checks for the presence of the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (Windows ADK) for Windows 10 and the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT) 2013 Update 2.
segment.target: This process also checks for the presence of the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (Windows ADK) for Windows 10 and the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT) 2013 Update 2.

segment.source: If these tools are not detected, they are downloaded and installed automatically.
segment.target: If these tools are not detected, they are downloaded and installed automatically.

segment.source: Click Next to continue.
segment.target: Click Next to continue.

segment.source: Note: As of SDA version 1.96.0405, SDA will install only the components of the Windows ADK that are required for deployment, as follows: Deployment tools User State Migration Tool (USMT) * Windows Preinstallation Environment (WinPE)
segment.target: Note: As of SDA version 1.96.0405, SDA will install only the components of the Windows ADK that are required for deployment, as follows: Deployment tools User State Migration Tool (USMT) * Windows Preinstallation Environment (WinPE)

segment.source: Note: As of SDA version 1.96.0405, SDA will install and use MDT 2013 Update 2.
segment.target: Note: As of SDA version 1.96.0405, SDA will install and use MDT 2013 Update 2.

segment.source: Earlier versions of SDA are compatible only with MDT 2013 Update 1.
segment.target: Earlier versions of SDA are compatible only with MDT 2013 Update 1.

segment.source: On the Windows 8.1 page, to create a Windows 10 deployment share, do not select the Would you like to support Windows 8.1 check box.
segment.target: On the Windows 8.1 page, to create a Windows 10 deployment share, do not select the Would you like to support Windows 8.1 check box.

segment.source: Click Next to continue.
segment.target: Click Next to continue.

segment.source: On the Windows 10 page, to create a Windows 10 deployment share, select the Would you like to support Windows 10 check box.
segment.target: On the Windows 10 page, to create a Windows 10 deployment share, select the Would you like to support Windows 10 check box.

segment.source: Supply the following information before you click Next to continue:
segment.target: Supply the following information before you click Next to continue:

segment.source: Configure Deployment Share for Windows 10
segment.target: Configure Deployment Share for Windows 10

segment.source: Local Path – Specify or browse to a location on the local storage device where you would like to store the deployment share files for the Windows 10 SDA deployment share.
segment.target: Local Path – Specify or browse to a location on the local storage device where you would like to store the deployment share files for the Windows 10 SDA deployment share.

segment.source: For example, E:SDAWin10 is the location specified in Figure 3.
segment.target: For example, E:SDAWin10 is the location specified in Figure 3.

segment.source: Share Name – Specify a name for the file share that will be used to access the deployment share on this server from the network.
segment.target: Share Name – Specify a name for the file share that will be used to access the deployment share on this server from the network.

segment.source: For example, SDAWin10 is the deployment share name shown in Figure 3.
segment.target: For example, SDAWin10 is the deployment share name shown in Figure 3.

segment.source: The local path folder is automatically shared by the SDA scripts under this name to the group Everyone with a permission level of Full Control.
segment.target: The local path folder is automatically shared by the SDA scripts under this name to the group Everyone with a permission level of Full Control.

segment.source: Windows 10 Deployment Services
segment.target: Windows 10 Deployment Services

segment.source: Select the Import boot media into the local Windows Deployment Service check box if you would like to boot your Surface devices from the network to perform the Windows deployment.
segment.target: Select the Import boot media into the local Windows Deployment Service check box if you would like to boot your Surface devices from the network to perform the Windows deployment.

segment.source: Windows Deployment Services must be installed and configured to respond to PXE boot requests.
segment.target: Windows Deployment Services must be installed and configured to respond to PXE boot requests.

segment.source: See Windows Deployment Services Getting Started Guide for Windows Server 2012 for more information about how to configure Windows Deployment Services for PXE boot.
segment.target: See Windows Deployment Services Getting Started Guide for Windows Server 2012 for more information about how to configure Windows Deployment Services for PXE boot.

segment.source: Windows 10 Source Files
segment.target: Windows 10 Source Files

segment.source: Local Path – Specify or browse to the root directory of Windows 10 installation files.
segment.target: Local Path – Specify or browse to the root directory of Windows 10 installation files.

segment.source: If you have an ISO file, mount it and browse to the root of the mounted drive.
segment.target: If you have an ISO file, mount it and browse to the root of the mounted drive.

segment.source: You must have a full set of source files, not just Install.wim.
segment.target: You must have a full set of source files, not just Install.wim.

segment.source: Specify Windows 10 deployment share options
segment.target: Specify Windows 10 deployment share options

segment.source: Figure 3.
segment.target: Figure 3.

segment.source: Specify Windows 10 deployment share options
segment.target: Specify Windows 10 deployment share options

segment.source: On the Configure page, select the check box next to each device or app that you want to include in your deployment share.
segment.target: On the Configure page, select the check box next to each device or app that you want to include in your deployment share.

segment.source: Note that Surface Pro 4 and Surface Book only support Windows 10 and are not available for the deployment of Windows 8.1.
segment.target: Note that Surface Pro 4 and Surface Book only support Windows 10 and are not available for the deployment of Windows 8.1.

segment.source: The Surface Firmware Tool is only applicable to Surface 3 and Surface Pro 3 and cannot be selected unless Surface 3 or Surface Pro 3 drivers are selected, as shown in Figure 4.
segment.target: The Surface Firmware Tool is only applicable to Surface 3 and Surface Pro 3 and cannot be selected unless Surface 3 or Surface Pro 3 drivers are selected, as shown in Figure 4.

segment.source: Click Next to continue.
segment.target: Click Next to continue.

segment.source: Firmware tool selection
segment.target: Firmware tool selection

segment.source: Figure 4.
segment.target: Figure 4.

segment.source: Selecting Surface Firmware Tool requires Surface Pro 3 drivers
segment.target: Selecting Surface Firmware Tool requires Surface Pro 3 drivers

segment.source: Note: You cannot select both Surface 3 and Surface 3 LTE models at the same time.
segment.target: Note: You cannot select both Surface 3 and Surface 3 LTE models at the same time.

segment.source: On the Summary page confirm your selections and click Finish to begin the creation of your deployment share.
segment.target: On the Summary page confirm your selections and click Finish to begin the creation of your deployment share.

segment.source: The process can take several minutes as files are downloaded, the tools are installed, and the deployment share is created.
segment.target: The process can take several minutes as files are downloaded, the tools are installed, and the deployment share is created.

segment.source: While the SDA scripts are creating your deployment share, an Installation Progress window will be displayed, as shown in Figure 5.
segment.target: While the SDA scripts are creating your deployment share, an Installation Progress window will be displayed, as shown in Figure 5.

segment.source: A typical SDA process includes:
segment.target: A typical SDA process includes:

segment.source: Download of Windows ADK
segment.target: Download of Windows ADK

segment.source: Installation of Windows ADK
segment.target: Installation of Windows ADK

segment.source: Download of MDT
segment.target: Download of MDT

segment.source: Installation of MDT
segment.target: Installation of MDT

segment.source: Download of Surface apps and drivers
segment.target: Download of Surface apps and drivers

segment.source: Creation of the deployment share
segment.target: Creation of the deployment share

segment.source: Import of Windows installation files into the deployment share
segment.target: Import of Windows installation files into the deployment share

segment.source: Import of the apps and drivers into the deployment share
segment.target: Import of the apps and drivers into the deployment share

segment.source: Creation of rules and task sequences for Windows deployment
segment.target: Creation of rules and task sequences for Windows deployment

segment.source: The installatin progress window
segment.target: The installatin progress window

segment.source: Figure 5.
segment.target: Figure 5.

segment.source: The Installation Progress window
segment.target: The Installation Progress window

segment.source: When the SDA process completes the creation of your deployment share, a Success window is displayed.
segment.target: When the SDA process completes the creation of your deployment share, a Success window is displayed.

segment.source: Click Finish to close the window.
segment.target: Click Finish to close the window.

segment.source: At this point your deployment share is now ready to perform a Windows deployment to Surface devices.
segment.target: At this point your deployment share is now ready to perform a Windows deployment to Surface devices.

segment.source: Optional: Create a deployment share without an Internet connection
segment.target: Optional: Create a deployment share without an Internet connection

segment.source: If you are unable to connect to the Internet with your deployment server, or if you want to download the Surface drivers and apps separately, you can specify a local source for the driver an app files at the time of deployment share creation.
segment.target: If you are unable to connect to the Internet with your deployment server, or if you want to download the Surface drivers and apps separately, you can specify a local source for the driver an app files at the time of deployment share creation.

segment.source: On the Configure page of the SDA wizard, select the Copy from a Local Directory check box, as shown in Figure 6.
segment.target: On the Configure page of the SDA wizard, select the Copy from a Local Directory check box, as shown in Figure 6.

segment.source: The Download from the Internet check box will be automatically deselected.
segment.target: The Download from the Internet check box will be automatically deselected.

segment.source: Enter the folder location where you have placed the driver and app files in the Local Path field, as shown in Figure 6.
segment.target: Enter the folder location where you have placed the driver and app files in the Local Path field, as shown in Figure 6.

segment.source: Note: All of the downloaded driver and applications files must be located in the same folder.
segment.target: Note: All of the downloaded driver and applications files must be located in the same folder.

segment.source: If a required driver or application file is missing from the selected folder when you click Next, a warning is displayed and the wizard will not proceed to the next step.
segment.target: If a required driver or application file is missing from the selected folder when you click Next, a warning is displayed and the wizard will not proceed to the next step.

segment.source: Note: The driver and app files do not need to be extracted from the downloaded .zip files.
segment.target: Note: The driver and app files do not need to be extracted from the downloaded .zip files.

segment.source: Note: Including Office 365 in your deployment share requires an Internet connection and cannot be performed if you use local files.
segment.target: Note: Including Office 365 in your deployment share requires an Internet connection and cannot be performed if you use local files.

segment.source: Specify Surface driver and app files
segment.target: Specify Surface driver and app files

segment.source: Figure 6.
segment.target: Figure 6.

segment.source: Specify the Surface driver and app files from a local path
segment.target: Specify the Surface driver and app files from a local path

segment.source: Note: The Copy from a Local Directory check box is only available in SDA version 1.90.0221 or later.
segment.target: Note: The Copy from a Local Directory check box is only available in SDA version 1.90.0221 or later.

segment.source: Optional: Prepare offline USB media
segment.target: Optional: Prepare offline USB media

segment.source: You can use USB media to perform an SDA deployment if your Surface device is unable to boot from the network.
segment.target: You can use USB media to perform an SDA deployment if your Surface device is unable to boot from the network.

segment.source: For example, if you do not have a Microsoft Surface Ethernet Adapter or Microsoft Surface dock to facilitate network boot (PXE boot).
segment.target: For example, if you do not have a Microsoft Surface Ethernet Adapter or Microsoft Surface dock to facilitate network boot (PXE boot).

segment.source: The USB drive produced by following these steps includes a complete copy of the SDA deployment share and can be run on a Surface device without a network connection.
segment.target: The USB drive produced by following these steps includes a complete copy of the SDA deployment share and can be run on a Surface device without a network connection.

segment.source: Note: The offline media files for the complete SDA deployment share are approximately 9 GB in size.
segment.target: Note: The offline media files for the complete SDA deployment share are approximately 9 GB in size.

segment.source: Your USB drive must be at least 9 GB in size.
segment.target: Your USB drive must be at least 9 GB in size.

segment.source: A 16 GB USB drive is recommended.
segment.target: A 16 GB USB drive is recommended.

segment.source: Before you can create bootable media files within the MDT Deployment Workbench or copy those files to a USB drive, you must first configure that USB drive to be bootable.
segment.target: Before you can create bootable media files within the MDT Deployment Workbench or copy those files to a USB drive, you must first configure that USB drive to be bootable.

segment.source: Using DiskPart, create a partition, format the partition as FAT32, and set the partition to be active.
segment.target: Using DiskPart, create a partition, format the partition as FAT32, and set the partition to be active.

segment.source: To run DiskPart, open an administrative PowerShell or Command Prompt window, and then run the following sequence of commands, as shown in Figure 7:
segment.target: To run DiskPart, open an administrative PowerShell or Command Prompt window, and then run the following sequence of commands, as shown in Figure 7:

segment.source: diskpart – Opens DiskPart to manage disks and partitions.
segment.target: diskpart – Opens DiskPart to manage disks and partitions.

segment.source: list disk – Displays a list of the disks available in your system; use this list to identify the disk number that corresponds with your USB drive.
segment.target: list disk – Displays a list of the disks available in your system; use this list to identify the disk number that corresponds with your USB drive.

segment.source: sel disk 2 – Selects your USB drive; use the number that corresponds with the disk in your system.
segment.target: sel disk 2 – Selects your USB drive; use the number that corresponds with the disk in your system.

segment.source: clean – Removes all configuration from your USB drive.
segment.target: clean – Removes all configuration from your USB drive.

segment.source: Warning: This step will remove all information from your drive.
segment.target: Warning: This step will remove all information from your drive.

segment.source: Verify that your USB drive does not contain any needed data before you perform the clean command.
segment.target: Verify that your USB drive does not contain any needed data before you perform the clean command.

segment.source: create part pri – Creates a primary partition on the USB drive.
segment.target: create part pri – Creates a primary partition on the USB drive.

segment.source: format fs=fat32 quick – Formats the partition with the FAT32 file system, performing a quick format.
segment.target: format fs=fat32 quick – Formats the partition with the FAT32 file system, performing a quick format.

segment.source: FAT32 is required to boot the device from UEFI systems like Surface devices.
segment.target: FAT32 is required to boot the device from UEFI systems like Surface devices.

segment.source: assign – Assigns the next available drive letter to the newly created FAT32 volume.
segment.target: assign – Assigns the next available drive letter to the newly created FAT32 volume.

segment.source: active – Sets the partition to be active, which is required to boot the volume.
segment.target: active – Sets the partition to be active, which is required to boot the volume.

segment.source: exit – Exits DiskPart, after which you can close the PowerShell or Command Prompt window.
segment.target: exit – Exits DiskPart, after which you can close the PowerShell or Command Prompt window.

segment.source: Use DiskPart to prepare a USB drive for boot
segment.target: Use DiskPart to prepare a USB drive for boot

segment.source: Figure 7.
segment.target: Figure 7.

segment.source: Use DiskPart to prepare a USB drive for boot
segment.target: Use DiskPart to prepare a USB drive for boot

segment.source: Note: You can format your USB drive with FAT32 from Disk Management, but you must still use DiskPart to set the partition as active for the drive to boot properly.
segment.target: Note: You can format your USB drive with FAT32 from Disk Management, but you must still use DiskPart to set the partition as active for the drive to boot properly.

segment.source: After you have prepared the USB drive for boot, the next step is to generate offline media from the SDA deployment share.
segment.target: After you have prepared the USB drive for boot, the next step is to generate offline media from the SDA deployment share.

segment.source: To create this media, follow these steps:
segment.target: To create this media, follow these steps:

segment.source: Open the Deployment Workbench from the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit group on your Start screen.
segment.target: Open the Deployment Workbench from the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit group on your Start screen.

segment.source: Expand the Deployment Shares node and the Microsoft Surface Deployment Accelerator deployment share.
segment.target: Expand the Deployment Shares node and the Microsoft Surface Deployment Accelerator deployment share.

segment.source: Expand the folder Advanced Configuration and select the Media folder.
segment.target: Expand the folder Advanced Configuration and select the Media folder.

segment.source: Right-click the Media folder and click New Media as shown in Figure 8 to start the New Media Wizard.
segment.target: Right-click the Media folder and click New Media as shown in Figure 8 to start the New Media Wizard.

segment.source: The Media folder of the SDA deployment share
segment.target: The Media folder of the SDA deployment share

segment.source: Figure 8.
segment.target: Figure 8.

segment.source: The Media folder of the SDA deployment share
segment.target: The Media folder of the SDA deployment share

segment.source: On the General Settings page in the Media path field, enter or browse to a folder where you will create the files for the new offline media.
segment.target: On the General Settings page in the Media path field, enter or browse to a folder where you will create the files for the new offline media.

segment.source: See the example E:SDAMedia in Figure 9.
segment.target: See the example E:SDAMedia in Figure 9.

segment.source: Leave the default profile Everything selected in the Selection profile drop-down menu, and then click Next.
segment.target: Leave the default profile Everything selected in the Selection profile drop-down menu, and then click Next.

segment.source: Specify a location and selection profile for your offline media
segment.target: Specify a location and selection profile for your offline media

segment.source: Figure 9.
segment.target: Figure 9.

segment.source: Specify a location and selection profile for your offline media
segment.target: Specify a location and selection profile for your offline media

segment.source: On the Summary page verify your selections, and then click Next to begin creation of the media.
segment.target: On the Summary page verify your selections, and then click Next to begin creation of the media.

segment.source: A Progress page is displayed while the media is created.
segment.target: A Progress page is displayed while the media is created.

segment.source: On the Confirmation page, click Finish to complete creation of the media.
segment.target: On the Confirmation page, click Finish to complete creation of the media.

segment.source: Right-click the Microsoft Surface Deployment Accelerator deployment share folder, click Properties, and then click the Rules tab as shown in Figure 10.
segment.target: Right-click the Microsoft Surface Deployment Accelerator deployment share folder, click Properties, and then click the Rules tab as shown in Figure 10.

segment.source: Rules of the SDA deployment share
segment.target: Rules of the SDA deployment share

segment.source: Figure 10.
segment.target: Figure 10.

segment.source: Rules of the SDA deployment share
segment.target: Rules of the SDA deployment share

segment.source: Use your mouse to highlight all of the text displayed in the text box of the Rules tab, and then press Ctrl+C to copy the text.
segment.target: Use your mouse to highlight all of the text displayed in the text box of the Rules tab, and then press Ctrl+C to copy the text.

segment.source: Click OK to close the Microsoft Surface Deployment Accelerator deployment share properties.
segment.target: Click OK to close the Microsoft Surface Deployment Accelerator deployment share properties.

segment.source: Right-click the newly created MEDIA001 item in the Media folder, click Properties, and then click the Rules tab.
segment.target: Right-click the newly created MEDIA001 item in the Media folder, click Properties, and then click the Rules tab.

segment.source: Use your mouse to highlight all of the text displayed in the text box of the Rules tab, and then press Ctrl+V to paste the text you copied from the Microsoft Surface Deployment Accelerator deployment share rules.
segment.target: Use your mouse to highlight all of the text displayed in the text box of the Rules tab, and then press Ctrl+V to paste the text you copied from the Microsoft Surface Deployment Accelerator deployment share rules.

segment.source: Right-click the Microsoft Surface Deployment Accelerator deployment share folder, click Properties, and then click the Rules tab again.
segment.target: Right-click the Microsoft Surface Deployment Accelerator deployment share folder, click Properties, and then click the Rules tab again.

segment.source: Click the Bootstrap.ini button to open Bootstrap.ini in Notepad.
segment.target: Click the Bootstrap.ini button to open Bootstrap.ini in Notepad.

segment.source: Press Ctrl+A to select all of the text in the window, and then press Ctrl+C to copy the text.
segment.target: Press Ctrl+A to select all of the text in the window, and then press Ctrl+C to copy the text.

segment.source: Close Bootstrap.ini and click OK in Microsoft Surface Deployment Accelerator deployment share properties to close the window.
segment.target: Close Bootstrap.ini and click OK in Microsoft Surface Deployment Accelerator deployment share properties to close the window.

segment.source: Right-click the newly created MEDIA001 item in the Media folder, click Properties, and then click the Rules tab again.
segment.target: Right-click the newly created MEDIA001 item in the Media folder, click Properties, and then click the Rules tab again.

segment.source: Click the Bootstrap.ini button to open Bootstrap.ini in Notepad.
segment.target: Click the Bootstrap.ini button to open Bootstrap.ini in Notepad.

segment.source: Press Ctrl+A to select all of the text in the window, then press Ctrl+V to paste the text from the SDA deployment share Bootstrap.ini file.
segment.target: Press Ctrl+A to select all of the text in the window, then press Ctrl+V to paste the text from the SDA deployment share Bootstrap.ini file.

segment.source: Delete the following lines from the Bootstrap.ini as shown in Figure 11, and then save the file:
segment.target: Delete the following lines from the Bootstrap.ini as shown in Figure 11, and then save the file:

segment.source: The Bootstrap.ini file
segment.target: The Bootstrap.ini file

segment.source: Figure 11.
segment.target: Figure 11.

segment.source: The Bootstrap.ini file of MEDIA001
segment.target: The Bootstrap.ini file of MEDIA001

segment.source: Close Bootstrap.ini and click OK in MEDIA001 deployment share properties to close the window.
segment.target: Close Bootstrap.ini and click OK in MEDIA001 deployment share properties to close the window.

segment.source: In the Deployment Workbench under the Media folder, right-click the newly created MEDIA001 and click Update Media Content, as shown in Figure 12.
segment.target: In the Deployment Workbench under the Media folder, right-click the newly created MEDIA001 and click Update Media Content, as shown in Figure 12.

segment.source: This will update the media files with the content of the Microsoft Surface Deployment Accelerator deployment share.
segment.target: This will update the media files with the content of the Microsoft Surface Deployment Accelerator deployment share.

segment.source: Select the Update Media Content option
segment.target: Select the Update Media Content option

segment.source: Figure 12.
segment.target: Figure 12.

segment.source: Select the Update Media Content option
segment.target: Select the Update Media Content option

segment.source: The Update Media Content window is displayed and shows the progress as the media files are created.
segment.target: The Update Media Content window is displayed and shows the progress as the media files are created.

segment.source: When the process completes, click Finish.
segment.target: When the process completes, click Finish.

segment.source: The final step is to copy the offline media files to your USB drive.
segment.target: The final step is to copy the offline media files to your USB drive.

segment.source: In File Explorer, open the path you specified in Step 5, for example E:SDAMedia.
segment.target: In File Explorer, open the path you specified in Step 5, for example E:SDAMedia.

segment.source: Copy all of the files from the Content folder to the root of the USB drive.
segment.target: Copy all of the files from the Content folder to the root of the USB drive.

segment.source: Your USB drive is now configured as bootable offline media that contains all of the resources required to perform a deployment to a Surface device.
segment.target: Your USB drive is now configured as bootable offline media that contains all of the resources required to perform a deployment to a Surface device.

segment.source: SDA task sequences
segment.target: SDA task sequences

segment.source: The SDA deployment share is configured with all of the resources required to perform a Windows deployment to a Surface device.
segment.target: The SDA deployment share is configured with all of the resources required to perform a Windows deployment to a Surface device.

segment.source: These resources include Windows source files, image, Surface drivers, and Surface apps.
segment.target: These resources include Windows source files, image, Surface drivers, and Surface apps.

segment.source: The deployment share also contains two pre-configured task sequences, as shown in Figure 13.
segment.target: The deployment share also contains two pre-configured task sequences, as shown in Figure 13.

segment.source: These task sequences contain the steps required to perform a deployment to a Surface device using the default Windows image from the installation media or to create a reference image complete with Windows updates and applications.
segment.target: These task sequences contain the steps required to perform a deployment to a Surface device using the default Windows image from the installation media or to create a reference image complete with Windows updates and applications.

segment.source: To learn more about task sequences, see MDT 2013 Update 2 Lite Touch components.
segment.target: To learn more about task sequences, see MDT 2013 Update 2 Lite Touch components.

segment.source: Task sequences in the Deployment Workbench
segment.target: Task sequences in the Deployment Workbench

segment.source: Figure 13.
segment.target: Figure 13.

segment.source: Task sequences in the Deployment Workbench
segment.target: Task sequences in the Deployment Workbench

segment.source: Deploy Microsoft Surface
segment.target: Deploy Microsoft Surface

segment.source: The 1 – Deploy Microsoft Surface task sequence is used to perform a complete deployment of Windows to a Surface device.
segment.target: The 1 – Deploy Microsoft Surface task sequence is used to perform a complete deployment of Windows to a Surface device.

segment.source: This task sequence is pre-configured by the SDA wizard and is ready to perform a deployment as soon as the wizard completes.
segment.target: This task sequence is pre-configured by the SDA wizard and is ready to perform a deployment as soon as the wizard completes.

segment.source: Running this task sequence on a Surface device deploys the unaltered Windows image copied directly from the Windows installation media you specified in the SDA wizard, along with the Surface drivers for your device.
segment.target: Running this task sequence on a Surface device deploys the unaltered Windows image copied directly from the Windows installation media you specified in the SDA wizard, along with the Surface drivers for your device.

segment.source: The drivers for your Surface device will be automatically selected through the pre-configured deployment share rules.
segment.target: The drivers for your Surface device will be automatically selected through the pre-configured deployment share rules.

segment.source: When you run the task sequence, you will be prompted to provide the following information:
segment.target: When you run the task sequence, you will be prompted to provide the following information:

segment.source: A computer name
segment.target: A computer name

segment.source: Your domain information and the credentials required to join the domain
segment.target: Your domain information and the credentials required to join the domain

segment.source: A product key, if one is required
segment.target: A product key, if one is required

segment.source: Note: If you are deploying the same version of Windows as the version that came on your device, no product key is required.
segment.target: Note: If you are deploying the same version of Windows as the version that came on your device, no product key is required.

segment.source: A time zone
segment.target: A time zone

segment.source: An Administrator password
segment.target: An Administrator password

segment.source: The Surface apps you specified on the Configure page of the SDA wizard are automatically installed when you run this task sequence on a Surface device.
segment.target: The Surface apps you specified on the Configure page of the SDA wizard are automatically installed when you run this task sequence on a Surface device.

segment.source: Create Windows reference image
segment.target: Create Windows reference image

segment.source: The 2 – Create Windows Reference Image task sequence is used to perform a deployment to a virtual machine for the purpose of capturing an image complete with Windows Updates for use in a deployment to Surface devices.
segment.target: The 2 – Create Windows Reference Image task sequence is used to perform a deployment to a virtual machine for the purpose of capturing an image complete with Windows Updates for use in a deployment to Surface devices.

segment.source: By installing Windows Updates in your reference image, you eliminate the need to download and install those updates on each deployed Surface device.
segment.target: By installing Windows Updates in your reference image, you eliminate the need to download and install those updates on each deployed Surface device.

segment.source: The deployment process with an up-to-date image is significantly faster and more efficient than performing a deployment first and then installing Windows Updates on each device.
segment.target: The deployment process with an up-to-date image is significantly faster and more efficient than performing a deployment first and then installing Windows Updates on each device.

segment.source: Like the 1 – Deploy Microsoft Surface task sequence, the 2 – Create Windows Reference Image task sequence performs a deployment of the unaltered Windows image directly from the installation media.
segment.target: Like the 1 – Deploy Microsoft Surface task sequence, the 2 – Create Windows Reference Image task sequence performs a deployment of the unaltered Windows image directly from the installation media.

segment.source: Creation of a reference image should always be performed on a virtual machine.
segment.target: Creation of a reference image should always be performed on a virtual machine.

segment.source: Using a virtual machine as your reference system helps to ensure that the resulting image is compatible with different hardware configurations.
segment.target: Using a virtual machine as your reference system helps to ensure that the resulting image is compatible with different hardware configurations.

segment.source: Note: Using a virtual machine when you create a reference image for Windows deployment is a recommended practice for performing Windows deployments with Microsoft deployment tools including the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit and System Center Configuration Manager.
segment.target: Note: Using a virtual machine when you create a reference image for Windows deployment is a recommended practice for performing Windows deployments with Microsoft deployment tools including the Microsoft Deployment Toolkit and System Center Configuration Manager.

segment.source: These Microsoft deployment technologies use the hardware agnostic images produced from a virtual machine and a collection of managed drivers to deploy to different configurations of hardware.
segment.target: These Microsoft deployment technologies use the hardware agnostic images produced from a virtual machine and a collection of managed drivers to deploy to different configurations of hardware.

segment.source: For more information, see Deploy a Windows 10 image using MDT 2013 Update 2.
segment.target: For more information, see Deploy a Windows 10 image using MDT 2013 Update 2.

segment.source: In addition to the information required by the 1 – Deploy Microsoft Surface task sequence, you will also be prompted to capture an image when you run this task sequence on your reference virtual machine.
segment.target: In addition to the information required by the 1 – Deploy Microsoft Surface task sequence, you will also be prompted to capture an image when you run this task sequence on your reference virtual machine.

segment.source: The Location and File name fields are automatically populated with the proper information for your deployment share.
segment.target: The Location and File name fields are automatically populated with the proper information for your deployment share.

segment.source: All that you need to do is select the Capture an image of this reference computer option when you are prompted on the Capture Image page of the Windows Deployment Wizard.
segment.target: All that you need to do is select the Capture an image of this reference computer option when you are prompted on the Capture Image page of the Windows Deployment Wizard.

segment.source: Deployment to Surface devices
segment.target: Deployment to Surface devices

segment.source: To perform a deployment from the SDA deployment share, follow this process on the Surface device:
segment.target: To perform a deployment from the SDA deployment share, follow this process on the Surface device:

segment.source: Boot the Surface device to MDT boot media for the SDA deployment share.
segment.target: Boot the Surface device to MDT boot media for the SDA deployment share.

segment.source: You can do this over the network by using PXE boot, or from a USB drive as described in the Optional: Prepare offline USB media section of this article.
segment.target: You can do this over the network by using PXE boot, or from a USB drive as described in the Optional: Prepare offline USB media section of this article.

segment.source: Select the deployment share for the version of Windows you intend to deploy and enter your credentials when you are prompted.
segment.target: Select the deployment share for the version of Windows you intend to deploy and enter your credentials when you are prompted.

segment.source: Select the task sequence you want to run, usually the 1 – Deploy Microsoft Surface task sequence.
segment.target: Select the task sequence you want to run, usually the 1 – Deploy Microsoft Surface task sequence.

segment.source: Address the task sequence prompts to pick applications, supply a password, and so on.
segment.target: Address the task sequence prompts to pick applications, supply a password, and so on.

segment.source: The task sequence performs the automated deployment using the options specified.
segment.target: The task sequence performs the automated deployment using the options specified.

segment.source: Boot the Surface device from the network
segment.target: Boot the Surface device from the network

segment.source: To boot the Surface device from the network, the Microsoft Surface Deployment Accelerator wizard must have been run on a Windows Server 2012 R2 or later environment that was configured with the Windows Deployment Services (WDS).
segment.target: To boot the Surface device from the network, the Microsoft Surface Deployment Accelerator wizard must have been run on a Windows Server 2012 R2 or later environment that was configured with the Windows Deployment Services (WDS).

segment.source: WDS must have been configured to respond to network boot (PXE boot) requests and the boot files must have been imported into WDS.
segment.target: WDS must have been configured to respond to network boot (PXE boot) requests and the boot files must have been imported into WDS.

segment.source: The SDA wizard will import these file automatically if the Import boot media into the local Windows Deployment Service check box was selected on the page for the version of Windows you intend to deploy.
segment.target: The SDA wizard will import these file automatically if the Import boot media into the local Windows Deployment Service check box was selected on the page for the version of Windows you intend to deploy.

segment.source: To boot the Surface device from the network, you must also use a Microsoft Surface Ethernet Adapter or the Ethernet port on a Microsoft Surface Dock.
segment.target: To boot the Surface device from the network, you must also use a Microsoft Surface Ethernet Adapter or the Ethernet port on a Microsoft Surface Dock.

segment.source: Third-party Ethernet adapters are not supported for network boot (PXE boot).
segment.target: Third-party Ethernet adapters are not supported for network boot (PXE boot).

segment.source: A keyboard is also required.
segment.target: A keyboard is also required.

segment.source: Both the Microsoft Surface Type Cover and keyboards connected via USB to the device or dock are supported.
segment.target: Both the Microsoft Surface Type Cover and keyboards connected via USB to the device or dock are supported.

segment.source: To instruct your Surface device to boot from the network, start with the device powered off and follow these steps:
segment.target: To instruct your Surface device to boot from the network, start with the device powered off and follow these steps:

segment.source: Press and hold the Volume Down button, press and release the Power button.
segment.target: Press and hold the Volume Down button, press and release the Power button.

segment.source: Continue holding the Volume Down button until the device has begun to boot from the network.
segment.target: Continue holding the Volume Down button until the device has begun to boot from the network.

segment.source: Press Enter when prompted by the dialog on the screen.
segment.target: Press Enter when prompted by the dialog on the screen.

segment.source: This prompt indicates that your device has found the WDS PXE server over the network.
segment.target: This prompt indicates that your device has found the WDS PXE server over the network.

segment.source: If you have configured more than one deployment share on this device, you will be prompted to select between the boot images for each deployment share.
segment.target: If you have configured more than one deployment share on this device, you will be prompted to select between the boot images for each deployment share.

segment.source: For example, if you created both a Windows 10 and a Windows 8.1 deployment share, you will be prompted to choose between these two options.
segment.target: For example, if you created both a Windows 10 and a Windows 8.1 deployment share, you will be prompted to choose between these two options.

segment.source: Enter the domain credentials that you use to log on to the server where SDA is installed when you are prompted, as shown in Figure 14.
segment.target: Enter the domain credentials that you use to log on to the server where SDA is installed when you are prompted, as shown in Figure 14.

segment.source: Prompt for credentials to the deployment share
segment.target: Prompt for credentials to the deployment share

segment.source: Figure 14.
segment.target: Figure 14.

segment.source: The prompt for credentials to the deployment share
segment.target: The prompt for credentials to the deployment share

segment.source: The Windows Deployment Wizard will start from the deployment share to walk you through the deployment process.
segment.target: The Windows Deployment Wizard will start from the deployment share to walk you through the deployment process.

segment.source: Alternatively boot the devices from the USB stick
segment.target: Alternatively boot the devices from the USB stick

segment.source: To boot a device from the USB stick:
segment.target: To boot a device from the USB stick:

segment.source: Press and hold the Volume Down button, press and release the Power button.
segment.target: Press and hold the Volume Down button, press and release the Power button.

segment.source: Continue holding the Volume Down button until the device has begun to boot from the USB drive.
segment.target: Continue holding the Volume Down button until the device has begun to boot from the USB drive.

segment.source: The Windows Deployment Wizard will start from the deployment share to walk you through the deployment process.
segment.target: The Windows Deployment Wizard will start from the deployment share to walk you through the deployment process.

segment.source: Run the Deploy Microsoft Surface task sequence
segment.target: Run the Deploy Microsoft Surface task sequence

segment.source: To run the Deploy Microsoft Surface task sequence:
segment.target: To run the Deploy Microsoft Surface task sequence:

segment.source: On the Task Sequence page, select the 1 – Deploy Microsoft Surface task sequence as shown in Figure 15, and then click Next.
segment.target: On the Task Sequence page, select the 1 – Deploy Microsoft Surface task sequence as shown in Figure 15, and then click Next.

segment.source: Select the task sequence
segment.target: Select the task sequence

segment.source: Figure 15.
segment.target: Figure 15.

segment.source: Select the 1 – Deploy Microsoft Surface task sequence
segment.target: Select the 1 – Deploy Microsoft Surface task sequence

segment.source: On the Computer Details page, type a name for the Surface device in the Computer Name box.
segment.target: On the Computer Details page, type a name for the Surface device in the Computer Name box.

segment.source: In the Join a domain section, type your domain name and credentials as shown in Figure 16, and then click Next.
segment.target: In the Join a domain section, type your domain name and credentials as shown in Figure 16, and then click Next.

segment.source: Computer name and domain credentials
segment.target: Computer name and domain credentials

segment.source: Figure 16.
segment.target: Figure 16.

segment.source: Enter the computer name and domain information
segment.target: Enter the computer name and domain information

segment.source: On the Product Key page, keep the No product key is required check box selected if you are deploying the same version and edition of Windows to your Surface devices as they came with from the factory.
segment.target: On the Product Key page, keep the No product key is required check box selected if you are deploying the same version and edition of Windows to your Surface devices as they came with from the factory.

segment.source: If you are deploying a different version or edition of Windows to the device, such as Windows Enterprise, select the licensing option that is applicable to your scenario.
segment.target: If you are deploying a different version or edition of Windows to the device, such as Windows Enterprise, select the licensing option that is applicable to your scenario.

segment.source: On the Locale and Time page, select your desired Language Settings and Time Zone, and then click Next.
segment.target: On the Locale and Time page, select your desired Language Settings and Time Zone, and then click Next.

segment.source: On the Administrator Password page, type a password for the local Administrator account on the Surface device, and then click Next.
segment.target: On the Administrator Password page, type a password for the local Administrator account on the Surface device, and then click Next.

segment.source: On the BitLocker page, select the Enable BitLocker option along with your desired configuration of BitLocker protectors if you want to encrypt the device.
segment.target: On the BitLocker page, select the Enable BitLocker option along with your desired configuration of BitLocker protectors if you want to encrypt the device.

segment.source: Otherwise, keep the Do not enable BitLocker for this computer check box selected, and then click Next.
segment.target: Otherwise, keep the Do not enable BitLocker for this computer check box selected, and then click Next.

segment.source: On the Ready page, verify your selections and then click Begin to start the automated deployment to this device.
segment.target: On the Ready page, verify your selections and then click Begin to start the automated deployment to this device.

segment.source: The deployment will not require user interaction again.
segment.target: The deployment will not require user interaction again.

segment.source: The Windows Deployment Wizard will close and an Installation Progress window is displayed to show progress of the task sequence as the image is applied and applications are installed (Figure 17).
segment.target: The Windows Deployment Wizard will close and an Installation Progress window is displayed to show progress of the task sequence as the image is applied and applications are installed (Figure 17).

segment.source: Installation progress window
segment.target: Installation progress window

segment.source: Figure 17.
segment.target: Figure 17.

segment.source: The Installation Progress window
segment.target: The Installation Progress window

segment.source: When the deployment task sequence completes, a Success window is displayed.
segment.target: When the deployment task sequence completes, a Success window is displayed.

segment.source: Click Finish to complete the deployment and begin using your Surface device.
segment.target: Click Finish to complete the deployment and begin using your Surface device.
